Markdown Support

Unify provides comprehensive Markdown support with YAML frontmatter, automatic head synthesis, and full DOM Cascade composition. Markdown files are processed into HTML and can use all of unify's layout and component features.

üìã What You'll Learn

This guide covers Markdown processing, YAML frontmatter, head synthesis, layout integration, and advanced content authoring techniques.

Markdown Fundamentals

File Processing

Unify treats .md files as first-class content sources:

  • Markdown is converted to semantic HTML
  • YAML frontmatter generates <head> metadata
  • Converted HTML follows DOM Cascade composition rules
  • Layouts are applied automatically or explicitly

Basic Markdown File

A simple Markdown file structure:

---
title: Getting Started with Unify
description: Learn how to build your first static site with unify
layout: blog
---

# Getting Started with Unify

Unify is a modern static site generator that makes building maintainable sites simple and enjoyable.

## Key Features

- **DOM Cascade composition** for layouts and components  
- **Zero runtime dependencies** in generated sites
- **Live development server** with hot reload
- **Markdown support** with YAML frontmatter

## Quick Start

Get started with unify in three steps:

1. Install unify: `npm install -g @fwdslsh/unify`
2. Initialize project: `unify init`
3. Start developing: `unify serve`

That's it! Your site is ready for development.

YAML Frontmatter

YAML frontmatter provides metadata and configuration for Markdown files. It must appear at the very beginning of the file, delimited by ---.

Supported Frontmatter Fields

Basic Metadata

---
title: string           # Page title (synthesized to <title>)
description: string     # Meta description (synthesized to <meta name="description">)
layout: string          # Layout file to apply
---

Advanced Head Synthesis

The head section allows complex metadata specification:

---
title: Advanced Unify Guide
description: Deep dive into unify's advanced features

head:
  meta:
    - name: robots
      content: "index,follow"
    - property: og:title
      content: "Advanced Unify Guide"
    - property: og:description  
      content: "Master unify's advanced features and patterns"
    - property: og:image
      content: "/images/advanced-guide.jpg"
    - property: og:url
      content: "https://example.com/guides/advanced"
      
  link:
    - rel: canonical
      href: "https://example.com/guides/advanced"
    - rel: preload
      as: image
      href: "/images/hero.avif"
    - rel: stylesheet
      href: "/css/guide.css"
      media: "screen"
      
  script:
    # External script
    - src: "/js/analytics.js"
      defer: true
      
    # JSON-LD structured data
    - type: "application/ld+json"
      json:
        "@context": "https://schema.org"
        "@type": "Article"
        headline: "Advanced Unify Guide"
        author:
          "@type": "Person"
          name: "John Doe"
        datePublished: "2024-01-15"
        dateModified: "2024-01-20"
        
  style:
    # Inline CSS
    - inline: |
        .guide-hero {
          background: linear-gradient(135deg, #667eea 0%, #764ba2 100%);
          color: white;
          contain: paint;
        }
        
    # External stylesheet with media query
    - href: "/css/print-guide.css"
      media: "print"
---

Head Synthesis Rules

Frontmatter is converted to HTML head elements following these rules:

  • title: Generates <title>Page Title</title>
  • description: Generates <meta name="description" content="...">
  • head.meta: Each item becomes <meta> with specified attributes
  • head.link: Each item becomes <link> with specified attributes
  • head.script: External scripts or JSON-LD blocks
  • head.style: Inline styles or external stylesheets

Frontmatter Validation

Unify validates frontmatter and provides helpful warnings:

‚ö†Ô∏è Validation Rules

  • Title conflicts: Warning if both title and head.meta title entries exist
  • Description conflicts: Warning if both description and matching head.meta exist
  • Empty items: Warning for empty entries in head arrays
  • Missing attributes: Warning for incomplete link, script, or style entries

Layout Integration

Layout Application

Markdown files can specify layouts in several ways:

1. Frontmatter Layout

---
layout: blog-post
---

# My Blog Post

Content goes here...

2. Automatic Layout Discovery

Without a layout field, unify discovers layouts automatically:

  1. Look for _layout.html in the Markdown file's directory
  2. Climb parent directories to source root
  3. Fall back to _includes/layout.html

3. CLI Default Layouts

# Set default layout for blog posts
unify build --default-layout "blog/**=_post.html"

# Global fallback layout
unify build --default-layout "_base.html"

Layout Precedence

Layout resolution follows this order:

  1. Frontmatter layout: Highest priority
  2. CLI --default-layout glob matches: Last matching pattern wins
  3. CLI --default-layout filename: Global fallback
  4. Auto-discovery: Directory-based discovery
  5. No layout: Basic HTML5 document wrapper

DOM Cascade with Markdown

Area-Based Composition

Markdown content can target specific areas in layouts using HTML blocks:

---
title: Product Launch
layout: marketing-page
---

<section class="unify-hero">

# Introducing Our New Product

Revolutionary technology meets elegant design.

<div class="hero-cta">
  <a href="/signup" class="btn btn-primary">Get Started Today</a>
</div>

</section>

<div class="unify-features">

## Key Features

- **Lightning Fast:** Optimized for performance
- **Secure by Design:** Built with security first
- **Developer Friendly:** Easy to integrate and customize

</div>

<section class="unify-testimonials">

> "This product changed how we work. Highly recommended!"
> ‚Äî Jane Smith, Tech Lead

Markdown + HTML Mixing

Unify's Markdown processor allows seamless mixing of Markdown and HTML:

# Markdown Heading

This is regular Markdown text.

<div class="custom-component">

## Markdown Inside HTML

You can use **Markdown formatting** inside HTML blocks.

- Lists work too
- Including *emphasis*

</div>

<!-- HTML comments are preserved -->

Back to regular Markdown content.

Advanced Markdown Features

Code Blocks with Syntax Highlighting

Unify supports fenced code blocks with language specification:

```javascript
// JavaScript example
const greeting = (name) => {
  return `Hello, ${name}!`;
};

console.log(greeting('World'));
```

```css
/* CSS example */
.hero {
  background: linear-gradient(135deg, #667eea 0%, #764ba2 100%);
  color: white;
  padding: 4rem 2rem;
  text-align: center;
}
```

```html
<!-- HTML example -->
<div data-unify="/_includes/card.html">
  <h3 class="unify-title">Card Title</h3>
  <p class="unify-body">Card content goes here</p>
</div>
```

Tables

GitHub Flavored Markdown table syntax is supported:

|---------|-------|-----|------------|

| Support | Email | Priority | Dedicated |
| Price | Free | $9/mo | Contact |

| Left Aligned | Center Aligned | Right Aligned |
|:-------------|:--------------:|--------------:|
| Left text    | Center text    | Right text    |
| More left    | More center    | More right    |

Best Practices

‚úÖ Markdown Authoring Guidelines

  • Consistent frontmatter: Use standard fields across similar content types
  • Semantic HTML: Use appropriate HTML5 elements in mixed content
  • Area classes: Target layout areas explicitly for predictable composition
  • Image optimization: Use appropriate formats and sizes for web delivery

Performance Optimization

  • Optimize images: Use modern formats (WebP, AVIF) and responsive sizing
  • Minimize head elements: Only include necessary meta tags and scripts
  • Lazy load assets: Preload critical resources, lazy load secondary content
  • Content structure: Use proper heading hierarchy for accessibility and SEO

SEO and Accessibility

  • Meta descriptions: Write compelling, accurate descriptions under 160 characters
  • Structured data: Use JSON-LD for rich snippets and search enhancement
  • Alt text: Provide descriptive alt text for all images
  • Heading structure: Use logical heading hierarchy (H1 ‚Üí H2 ‚Üí H3)

Integration with Components

Including Components in Markdown

Use HTML blocks to include components within Markdown content:

# Product Comparison

Compare our different pricing tiers:

<div data-unify="/_includes/pricing-table.html">
  <!-- Pricing data can be customized here -->
</div>

## Need help choosing?

Contact our sales team for personalized recommendations.

<div data-unify="/_includes/contact-form.html">
  <div class="unify-title">
    <h3>Get in Touch</h3>
  </div>
  <div class="unify-message">
    <p>Tell us about your project and we'll help you choose the right plan.</p>
  </div>
</div>

Markdown Components

Components can also be Markdown files:

<!-- _includes/faq-item.md -->
---
title: Default Question
---

## {{ frontmatter.title }}

Default answer content goes here. This can include:

- **Markdown formatting**
- [Links](https://example.com)
- `Code snippets`

> Important notes can be highlighted in blockquotes.

‚ö†Ô∏è Markdown Limitations

  • No frontmatter in HTML: HTML files cannot use YAML frontmatter
  • No head elements in body: Markdown files cannot include <head> in content
  • Processing order: Markdown is converted before DOM Cascade composition
  • Syntax conflicts: Some Markdown syntax may conflict with HTML attributes

Troubleshooting

Common Issues

Frontmatter Not Processing

  • Ensure YAML frontmatter is at the very beginning of the file
  • Use proper YAML syntax with --- delimiters
  • Check for invisible characters or encoding issues

Layout Not Applied

  • Verify layout file exists at specified path
  • Check layout file has proper DOM Cascade areas
  • Review layout precedence rules

HTML Not Rendering

  • Ensure HTML blocks have proper spacing around them
  • Check for conflicting Markdown syntax
  • Validate HTML syntax within Markdown
